>>PHILIP HAMMOND: In just 16 weeks' time,
Britain will face a decision that will shape

124.text:
the course of our nation's history for a generation
or more: Should we remain within the European

130.text:
Union on the terms negotiated by David Cameron
or should we withdraw from membership and

138.text:
The Government's clear view is that we are
stronger, safer and better off remaining within

145.text:
a reformed European Union; Stronger, because
our global influence is enhanced by being

151.text:
a leading member of the world's largest trading
bloc, safer because of the work we do together

158.text:
with EU partners to strengthen our defences
against organised crime and terrorism, and

164.text:
better off because of our access to a market
of 500 million consumers. The deal that the

171.text:
Prime Minister won in Brussels twelve days
ago ensures that the UK can remain in the

178.text:
EU with a special status: outside the Euro;
outside Schengen; with an opt-in on Justice

185.text:
and Home Affairs matters, an exemption from
`ever closer union' and a new mechanism to

191.text:
limit access to our benefits system for EU
migrants.

196.text:
That deal protects British jobs by ensuring
a level playing field in Europe for British

202.text:
business, safeguarding the pound and the Bank
of England. It will boost EU competitiveness

209.text:
by completing the European Single Market,
prioritising international trade agreements,

214.text:
and cutting the burden of EU
regulation. And it provides an emergency brake

220.text:
to limit access to our benefits system for
EU migrants and gives us new powers to exclude

226.text:
criminals and to stop exporting child benefits
at UK rates.

232.text: I think that's a good deal for Britain.

235.text:
And as the British people decide whether to
take it and remain in a reformed European

241.text:
Union, offering Britain the best of both worlds
or to take a leap into the unknown, I want

248.text:
to shine some light on what a future outside
the EU might look like for Britain. Because

255.text:
the Leave campaign have so far failed to do
so.

260.text:
On Monday we published a paper setting out
the process by which we would exit the EU

265.text:
following a `leave' vote. Today we are publishing
a paper outlining the principal alternatives

272.text:
to membership. I am laying the paper in Parliament
this morning and it will be available online.

278.text: I now want to summarise our main findings.

282.text:
But first, I want to be clear about the process
of negotiating an exit, and our future relationship

289.text:
with the EU. Because it would become the defining
national project for several years. A vote

297.text:
to leave on June 23rd would trigger a two
year window, under the terms of the Treaties,

303.text:
for the UK to negotiate the terms of our exit
from the EU. And in the meantime, we will

310.text:
be able to offer British businesses no assurance
at all about their future access to EU, or

317.text:
for that matter, to other markets. We will
have nothing to say to American, Japanese,

324.text:
Chinese companies looking for a base in which
to invest to supply the EU market. Our economy

333.text:
would literally be on hold, whilst our competitors,
including our European competitors, forge

341.text:
And at the end of two years, there is no guarantee
at all that we would have reached agreement,

348.text:
but our exit would be automatic unless every
single member of the remaining EU agreed to

358.text:
Our access to the Single Market would cease.
Our trading agreements with more than 50 markets

363.text:
around the world would lapse, with an immediate
and negative effect on confidence, on growth,

373.text:
Years of uncertainty for Britain, just as
we are getting back on our feet.

379.text:
And, like any divorce, the negotiations with
our former EU partners are likely to be difficult.

389.text:
The leaders of the remaining Member States
would have their own pressing domestic political

394.text:
calculations to consider. In many cases people
in their countries already think that they've

402.text:
gone the extra mile for Britain. They'd be
frustrated that having done that, to offer

409.text:
Britain a special � and unique � status
in the EU, their efforts had been in vain.

415.text:
And frankly they'd be apprehensive as well,
apprehensive of the `contagion' that a Brexit

421.text: might bring to their own countries.

424.text:
So let's be clear, if we reject the special
status the prime minister has painstakingly

429.text:
negotiated, then we can expect the goodwill
that we have seen towards Britain during these

435.text:
negotiations to evaporate with them. The blunt
fact is that our former partners in Britain

443.text:
will not feel that they owe us any favours;
they will have no interest in helping us to

452.text:
And to those who argue, as some have done,
that `they need us more than we need them',

458.text:
I say `sadly not the case'. Even if the only
factor was trade, and it certainly isn't,

465.text:
the fact is that in 2014 half of the goods
Britain exported went to the EU - just 7%

476.text: of the goods the EU exported came to the UK.

481.text:
Our exit negotiation and our attempts to forge
some sort of new relationship are likely to

487.text: involve some tough and protracted discussions.

493.text: So what, realistically, are the alternatives?

495.text:
At different times, the various Leave campaigns
have suggested over 20 different models to

502.text:
choose from including the current EU deals
with Norway, Switzerland, Iceland, Lichtenstein,

508.text:
Canada, Turkey, Korea, Macedonia. Even Peru
and Vanuatu!

514.text:
But they have been unable to settle on one.
In fact, they have deliberately avoided trying

520.text:
because they cannot point to an example which
is better than the special status within the

526.text:
EU that we now have on offer. Every other
option has significant drawbacks. And the

533.text:
simple truth is that we cannot know what
deal a Britain outside the EU would end up

541.text:
The evidence, however, and that is what this
paper is about today, suggests that there

546.text:
are three basic models: The Norway model;
the bilateral model, a negotiated bilateral

554.text:
agreement, such as the free trade deals used
by Switzerland, Canada, Korea and Turkey;

560.text:
or as a default, the WTO (World Trade Organisation)
model.

565.text: Let me take each in turn.

568.text:
Norway. Norway, along with Iceland and Liechtenstein,
is a member of the European Economic Area

577.text:
And Norway is the non-EU country with the
greatest, although still not total, access

584.text:
to the Single Market. It does have the same
access in services as the UK has now. But

592.text:
it is outside the Customs Union, meaning that
all trade in goods between the EU and Norway

597.text:
is subject to customs checks and Rules of
Origin. And

601.text: it faces tariffs in agriculture and fish.

605.text:
Norway does also take part in some areas of
non-economic co-operation, like counter terrorism.

611.text:
But it pays a price for these privileges.
It has to adopt most EU rules, without any

617.text:
say in making them. It pays roughly the same
into the EU per person as the UK does.

625.text:
And, crucially, it is obliged to accept the
free movement of people from both EU and EEA

633.text:
countries: migrants in Norway have the same
right to access benefits as Norwegians. Today,

641.text:
there is a higher proportion of EU nationals
resident in Norway than there is in the UK.

649.text:
The case of Norway neatly demonstrates the
dilemma for Leave: the price of access to

656.text:
the single market is freedom of movement.
And the more access to the market they promise,

663.text:
the more empty the boast that they would be
able to unilaterally control migration from

670.text:
And I say this: If we care about real sovereignty,
about being able to shape the decisions which

677.text:
affect us, then the Norway model is definitely
not for us.

683.text:
Bilateral. What if we were to make a bilateral
agreement? After all, the EU has a broad range

688.text:
of trade agreements with other countries,
such as Switzerland, Turkey or Canada.

694.text:
Some recommend the Swiss model. But it has
taken Switzerland two decades to negotiate

700.text:
more than one hundred separate agreements
that it currently has with the EU. Even then,

707.text:
they only have partial access to the Single
Market. They face barriers for agriculture

712.text:
and, crucially from our point of view, for
services. And once again, they are bound by

718.text:
the principle of free movement of people,
with almost four times as many resident EU

724.text: nationals per capita as in the UK.

729.text:
Others point to Turkey as a model to follow.
Now Turkey of course is a candidate country

734.text:
for membership and has been in a Customs Union
with the EU since 1995. It has full access

741.text:
to the single market for industrial and processed
agricultural goods, where it is subject to

749.text:
EU regulations, but no access for raw
agricultural products nor again, crucially,

759.text:
As part of the Customs Unions, Turkey must
align its external tariffs with the EU. And

764.text:
when the EU signs a trade deal with a third
country, Turkey must open its market on the

769.text:
same terms. But this is not reciprocal, and
the third country is not obliged to open its

779.text:
Turkey does not take part in policing and
criminal justice measures; has only limited

783.text:
co-operation on international security, and
it has no say in EU decision-making.

791.text:
And our conclusion is that the Turkish model
would clearly not work for Britain.

796.text:
What about Canada? The EU-Canada deal has
taken seven years and counting to finalise

803.text:
and has still not been approved by the European
Parliament! When it happens, and it will happen,

809.text:
it will be the most extensive bilateral agreement
the EU has ever made. It gives market access

817.text:
without the free movement of
people, and without paying into the EU budget.

823.text:
But Canada is not a European country. And
let's be clear: the Canadian trade deal does

829.text:
not even remotely replicate the access we
have as an EU member.

835.text:
Canadian manufacturers will only have tariff-free
access if they meet EU `rules of origin'.

842.text:
So Canadian products, like cars, with complex
international supply chains may still face

847.text:
tariffs. Canadian financial services providers
can't supply directly to the EU market. They

855.text:
have to set up subsidiaries inside EU member
states operating under EU regulations; exporting

862.text:
Canadian jobs. This would really matter for
Britain: our services sector is four-fifths

869.text:
(80%) of the UK economy. We are the second
largest exporter of services in the world.

876.text:
And the EU is our largest market for those
services.

884.text:
The EU also sets regulatory standards on many
products: cars, pharmaceuticals, toys, foodstuffs

890.text: and Canada won't have a say over any of them.

896.text:
The fact is, none of the bilateral free trade
models would offer anything like the access

903.text:
we have now to the Single Market and many
of them would require adoption of EU regulations

911.text:
and freedom of movement rules. What about
Britain's trade with the rest of the world?

917.text:
We currently benefit from EU trade deals
with over 50 different countries. And these

923.text:
deals have been based on the negotiating muscle
of a bloc with 500m consumers and a quarter

931.text:
of the world's GDP. Renegotiating them as
a single country would take many, many years.

939.text:
Years in which British businesses would be
squeezed out of traditional markets and

944.text:
with no guarantee at the end of the process
we could get terms as good as we have now.

952.text:
Some have said we should focus our attention
on deals with the Anglosphere and the Commonwealth.

959.text:
But the EU already either has, or is negotiating,
trade deals with all the biggest Commonwealth

964.text:
countries, and none of our allies wants us
to leave the EU. Not Australia, not New Zealand,

972.text:
not Canada, not the US. In fact, the only
country who would like us to leave the EU

980.text:
is Russia. That should tell us all we need
to know.

985.text:
WTO: Let's look for a moment now at the default
option � the World Trade Organisation rules,

991.text:
which is where we will end up if we leave
without a deal agreed. For anyone who wants

999.text:
to ensure a clean break with the EU, the WTO
model is the only honest model. WTO rules

1007.text:
mean we could sell into the Single Market,
but

1010.text:
at a price: The EU imposes a `common external
tariff' on goods and services from countries

1017.text:
outside the EU who don't have free trade deals
agreed.

1021.text:
10% on cars. 30% on confectionery. 36% on
dairy produce.

1030.text:
Our exports would cost more and so be less
competitive. That will cost British jobs.

1036.text:
And if we reciprocated, our imports would
cost more too meaning higher prices in our

1044.text:
And that would not be all. Under WTO rules,
we couldn't differentiate between countries.

1051.text:
So, for example, if we decided to allow Irish
goods to enter the UK tariff-free, we would

1057.text:
have to do the same for all 160 countries
in the WTO � putting British jobs at risk

1066.text:
Because, as EU members, the common external
tariffs protect our industries from undercutting

1072.text:
from outside the EU, while allowing us to
import from Europe without tariffs pushing

1078.text:
up costs. Outside the EU, it would be all
or nothing under WTO rules.

1086.text:
And for our crucial services sector, without
a preferential trade agreement, UK businesses

1093.text:
would only be guaranteed access under the
General Agreement on Trade in Services. This

1098.text:
is a much more basic framework, providing
much less access to markets.

1105.text:
So on even a cursory inspection, the WTO model
does not deliver for Britain. It would be

1112.text:
bad for business; bad for jobs; bad for growth.
Bad for Britain.

1117.text:
Our choice: leadership of a reformed EU or
a leap into the dark.

1118.text:
The truth is, the Leave campaigns cannot point
to a credible alternative. They are unable

1125.text:
or unwilling to address their core dilemma:
the price for any significant level of access

1132.text:
to the single market for goods, let alone
services, is acceptance of free movement of

1138.text:
people. The EU has been remarkably consistent
in its dealings with other European countries.

1145.text:
And the more access to the single market the
Leave campaign promises, the more hollow their

1156.text:
So what should we conclude from this analysis?
That none of the `post-exit' options offer

1163.text:
anything close to the best-of-both-worlds,
special-status, deal that the Prime Minister

1169.text:
has negotiated in the European Union. And
the most often cited model, Norway, would

1176.text:
offer us, quite literally, the worst of both
worlds. Paying as if we remained a member

1184.text:
of the European Union, subject to the European
Union and obliged to observe the principle

1192.text:
of free movement to gain access to the single
market that we have now, without any say in

1200.text:
how those rules are made and without any say
over how the European Union is run.

1207.text:
Negotiating any kind of arrangement with 27
countries we that have just rejected will

1213.text:
almost certainly take years, will not give
full access to the Single Market without contributing

1219.text:
to the budget, accepting all the rules, allowing
free movement, and will leave us with no seat

1225.text:
at the table. To me, that's less
sovereignty, not more sovereignty.

1232.text:
Balancing the burdens and the benefits, none
of the options that are remotely likely to

1239.text:
be deliverable comes close to matching the
deal that we already have on the table.

1245.text: So why would we take a leap in the dark?

1248.text:
Why would we risk the effect of years of uncertainty
on the British economy?

1254.text:
Why would we take that chance with our children's
future - risking our influence, our prosperity

1263.text:
When by voting to remain, we can have the
best of both worlds in a reformed EU; rather

1270.text:
than the worst of both outside. A powerful
voice inside Europe; instead of a lonely voice

1278.text:
outside. A Great Britain, stronger, safer
and better off within the EU.
